titleStmt.title: Diary Entry of Marion Walter Carmichael February 26, 1898, an electronic edition

projectDesc.p: This text was created by the Lewis H. Beck Center as a part of the Oxford Experience Project. Project participants intend for this encoded text, as well as all texts produced by this project, to be made available on the web for educational, scholarly and pedagogical purposes.

samplingDecl.p: The archival material has been transcribed and encoded. Paratextual elements may be provided as digital images only, with some exceptions.

editorialDecl.p: Processing this electronic text file began by creating TIFF images of each page using either a flatbed scanner. Text pages were captured in color at 300dpi. These digital images were converted to an electronic text file by transcription. The text files produced have been proofread against the original document or a JPEG image of the original. This proofread text file has then been encoded using the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines. For the details of Level 3 encoding, please see the webpage for TEI Guidelines for Best Encoding practices at http://www.indiana.edu/~letrs/tei/. Encoders silently replaced em dashes with two dashes. Page numbers and other text such as titles displayed in brackets have been added by the encoder and do not appear in the original text.

change.item: XML tags inserted in compliance with TEI guidelines.

pb.p: In some near or remote future, should my eye change to fall upon this page, I shall recall in all distinctness this day - Feb 26th, 1898.

How miserable are the effects of negligence of duty! For more than three weeks I have delayed writing my spring term speeches, and not with last night did I try hard to accomplish the task. But I do! I accomplished nothing! I read a a part of Emerson's essay on self-reliance, thinking that it might quicken mental action but after trying to write until half past one o'clock, I could do nothing that was satisfactory to my worn mind. I went to bed, slept until nearly seven o'clock and arose with the determination of making another trick this morning. So after breakfast I gathered ripe Lec's History of the W.S., Sargents Standard Speaker, and writing tablet and set out for the woods. The morning is fright and nature seems to be every aid. I am now in a little patch of fine woods of fine on ten years growth by an old gully about ten feet deep which in all probability is the result of thought led antebellum farming, about one mile north west of Andrew Hall. What success I may have today I cannot now predict. But this much I know, that there is no probability of my enjoying the Arbor Day exercises of the class of '98, of which I am a member, unless I make one more earnest effort to write my contemplated eulogy on Thomas Jefferson. May my mind be quickened by Him who has all power.

pb.dateline:
March 3rd, 1898
This has been another trying day in my life. I arose this morning being awakened by the cook's call for the keys to kitchen, and learned that my butler was still sick and that the boy in his place had not returned. Consequent by I had to look after the dinning room and did get to study my mental philosophy lesson on I should. And was called reform failed, and was rebulked. But alas! The sun does not shine bright every day.
